items.name: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag
items.summary: The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag.

items.name: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User
items.summary: The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

items.name: Struts: Duplicate Validation Forms
items.summary: The product uses multiple validation forms with the same name, which might cause the Struts Validator to validate a form that the programmer does not expect.

items.name: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames
items.summary: The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with.

items.name: Use of Web Link to Untrusted Target with window.opener Access
items.summary: The web application produces links to untrusted external sites outside of its sphere of control, but it does not properly prevent the external site from modifying security-critical properties of the window.opener object, such as the location property.

items.name: Incomplete Comparison with Missing Factors
items.summary: The product performs a comparison between entities that must consider multiple factors or characteristics of each entity, but the comparison does not include one or more of these factors.

items.name: Comparison of Incompatible Types
items.summary: The product performs a comparison between two entities, but the entities are of different, incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared.

items.name: Comparison Using Wrong Factors
items.summary: The code performs a comparison between two entities, but the comparison examines the wrong factors or characteristics of the entities, which can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.

items.name: Struts: Incomplete validate() Method Definition
items.summary: The product has a validator form that either does not define a validate() method, or defines a validate() method but does not call super.validate().

items.name: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code
items.summary: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

items.name: Insecure Automated Optimizations
items.summary: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code, e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance, but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.

items.name: Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations in Automated Recognition Mechanism
items.summary: The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.

items.name: Struts: Form Bean Does Not Extend Validation Class
items.summary: If a form bean does not extend an ActionForm subclass of the Validator framework, it can expose the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

items.name: Use of Redundant Code
items.summary: The product has multiple functions, methods, procedures, macros, etc. that contain the same code.

items.name: Static Member Data Element outside of a Singleton Class Element
items.summary: The code contains a member element that is declared as static (but not final), in which its parent class element is not a singleton class - that is, a class element that can be used only once in the 'to' association of a Create action.

items.name: Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements
items.summary: The product uses a data element that has an excessively large number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects.

items.name: Architecture with Number of Horizontal Layers Outside of Expected Range
items.summary: The product's architecture contains too many - or too few - horizontal layers.

items.name: Parent Class with a Virtual Destructor and a Child Class without a Virtual Destructor
items.summary: A parent class has a virtual destructor method, but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor.

items.name: Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation
items.summary: The product creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations.

items.name: Modules with Circular Dependencies
items.summary: The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

items.name: Invokable Control Element with Large Number of Outward Calls
items.summary: The code contains callable control elements that contain an excessively large number of references to other application objects external to the context of the callable, i.e. a Fan-Out value that is excessively large.

items.name: Excessive Data Query Operations in a Large Data Table
items.summary: The product performs a data query with a large number of joins and sub-queries on a large data table.

items.name: Struts: Form Field Without Validator
items.summary: The product has a form field that is not validated by a corresponding validation form, which can introduce other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

items.name: Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop
items.summary: The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or indirectly consumes platform resources, e.g. messaging, sessions, locks, or file descriptors.

items.name: Initialization with Hard-Coded Network Resource Configuration Data
items.summary: The product initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers.

items.name: Excessive Use of Hard-Coded Literals in Initialization
items.summary: The product initializes a data element using a hard-coded literal that is not a simple integer or static constant element.

items.name: Missing Documentation for Design
items.summary: The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed.

items.name: Invocation of a Control Element at an Unnecessarily Deep Horizontal Layer
items.summary: The code at one architectural layer invokes code that resides at a deeper layer than the adjacent layer, i.e., the invocation skips at least one layer, and the invoked code is not part of a vertical utility layer that can be referenced from any horizontal layer.

items.name: Multiple Inheritance from Concrete Classes
items.summary: The product contains a class with inheritance from more than one concrete class.

items.name: Invokable Control Element with Variadic Parameters
items.summary: A named-callable or method control element has a signature that supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments.

items.name: Data Access Operations Outside of Expected Data Manager Component
items.summary: The product uses a dedicated, central data manager component as required by design, but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager.

items.name: Invokable Control Element in Multi-Thread Context with non-Final Static Storable or Member Element
items.summary: The code contains a function or method that operates in a multi-threaded environment but owns an unsafe non-final static storable or member data element.

items.name: Insufficient Technical Documentation
items.summary: The product does not contain sufficient technical or engineering documentation (whether on paper or in electronic form) that contains descriptions of all the relevant software/hardware elements of the product, such as its usage, structure, architectural components, interfaces, design, implementation, configuration, operation, etc.

items.name: Struts: Plug-in Framework not in Use
items.summary: When an application does not use an input validation framework such as the Struts Validator, there is a greater risk of introducing weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

items.name: Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses
items.summary: The product performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.

items.name: Insufficient Encapsulation
items.summary: The product does not sufficiently hide the internal representation and implementation details of data or methods, which might allow external components or modules to modify data unexpectedly, invoke unexpected functionality, or introduce dependencies that the programmer did not intend.

items.name: Parent Class with References to Child Class
items.summary: The code has a parent class that contains references to a child class, its methods, or its members.

items.name: Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block
items.summary: A static code block creates an instance of a class.

items.name: Invokable Control Element with Signature Containing an Excessive Number of Parameters
items.summary: The product contains a function, subroutine, or method whose signature has an unnecessarily large number of parameters/arguments.

items.name: Runtime Resource Management Control Element in a Component Built to Run on Application Servers
items.summary: The product uses deployed components from application servers, but it also uses low-level functions/methods for management of resources, instead of the API provided by the application server.

items.name: Missing Serialization Control Element
items.summary: The product contains a serializable data element that does not have an associated serialization method.

items.name: Excessive Execution of Sequential Searches of Data Resource
items.summary: The product contains a data query against an SQL table or view that is configured in a way that does not utilize an index and may cause sequential searches to be performed.

items.name: Inconsistency Between Implementation and Documented Design
items.summary: The implementation of the product is not consistent with the design as described within the relevant documentation.

items.name: Empty Exception Block
items.summary: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code, i.e. is empty.

items.name: Struts: Unused Validation Form
items.summary: An unused validation form indicates that validation logic is not up-to-date.

items.name: Serializable Data Element Containing non-Serializable Item Elements
items.summary: The product contains a serializable, storable data element such as a field or member, but the data element contains member elements that are not serializable.

items.name: Empty Code Block
items.summary: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code, i.e., the block is empty.

items.name: Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling
items.summary: The product accesses a data resource through a database without using a connection pooling capability.

items.name: Non-SQL Invokable Control Element with Excessive Number of Data Resource Accesses
items.summary: The product contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses/queries that are sent through a data manager, i.e., does not use efficient database capabilities.

items.name: Class with Excessively Deep Inheritance
items.summary: A class has an inheritance level that is too high, i.e., it has a large number of parent classes.

items.name: Unconditional Control Flow Transfer outside of Switch Block
items.summary: The product performs unconditional control transfer (such as a "goto") in code outside of a branching structure such as a switch block.

items.name: Insufficient Adherence to Expected Conventions
items.summary: The product's architecture, source code, design, documentation, or other artifact does not follow required conventions.

items.name: Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator
items.summary: The code performs a comparison such as an equality test between two float (floating point) values, but it uses comparison operators that do not account for the possibility of loss of precision.

items.name: Inappropriate Source Code Style or Formatting
items.summary: The source code does not follow desired style or formatting for indentation, white space, comments, etc.

items.name: Parent Class without Virtual Destructor Method
items.summary: A parent class contains one or more child classes, but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method.

items.name: Struts: Unvalidated Action Form
items.summary: Every Action Form must have a corresponding validation form.

items.name: Source Code File with Excessive Number of Lines of Code
items.summary: A source code file has too many lines of code.

items.name: Class Instance Self Destruction Control Element
items.summary: The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself.

items.name: Data Access from Outside Expected Data Manager Component
items.summary: The product is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database, but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component.

items.name: Invokable Control Element with Excessive File or Data Access Operations
items.summary: A function or method contains too many operations that utilize a data manager or file resource.

items.name: Invokable Control Element with Excessive Volume of Commented-out Code
items.summary: A function, method, procedure, etc. contains an excessive amount of code that has been commented out within its body.

items.name: Class with Excessive Number of Child Classes
items.summary: A class contains an unnecessarily large number of children.

items.name: Class with Virtual Method without a Virtual Destructor
items.summary: A class contains a virtual method, but the method does not have an associated virtual destructor.

items.name: Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout
items.summary: The code has a synchronous call to a remote resource, but there is no timeout for the call, or the timeout is set to infinite.

items.name: Large Data Table with Excessive Number of Indices
items.summary: The product uses a large data table that contains an excessively large number of indices.

items.name: Struts: Validator Turned Off
items.summary: Automatic filtering via a Struts bean has been turned off, which disables the Struts Validator and custom validation logic. This exposes the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

items.name: Method Containing Access of a Member Element from Another Class
items.summary: A method for a class performs an operation that directly accesses a member element from another class.

items.name: Use of Object without Invoking Destructor Method
items.summary: The product contains a method that accesses an object but does not later invoke the element's associated finalize/destructor method.

items.name: Use of Same Invokable Control Element in Multiple Architectural Layers
items.summary: The product uses the same control element across multiple architectural layers.

items.name: Excessively Complex Data Representation
items.summary: The product uses an unnecessarily complex internal representation for its data structures or interrelationships between those structures.

items.name: Excessive Index Range Scan for a Data Resource
items.summary: The product contains an index range scan for a large data table, but the scan can cover a large number of rows.

items.name: Loop Condition Value Update within the Loop
items.summary: The product uses a loop with a control flow condition based on a value that is updated within the body of the loop.

items.name: Singleton Class Instance Creation without Proper Locking or Synchronization
items.summary: The product implements a Singleton design pattern but does not use appropriate locking or other synchronization mechanism to ensure that the singleton class is only instantiated once.

items.name: Persistent Storable Data Element without Associated Comparison Control Element
items.summary: The product uses a storable data element that does not have all of the associated functions or methods that are necessary to support comparison.

items.name: Data Element containing Pointer Item without Proper Copy Control Element
items.summary: The code contains a data element with a pointer that does not have an associated copy or constructor method.

items.name: Inconsistent Naming Conventions for Identifiers
items.summary: The product's code, documentation, or other artifacts do not consistently use the same naming conventions for variables, callables, groups of related callables, I/O capabilities, data types, file names, or similar types of elements.

items.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Creating Debug Binary
items.summary: Debugging messages help attackers learn about the system and plan a form of attack.

items.name: Struts: Validator Without Form Field
items.summary: Validation fields that do not appear in forms they are associated with indicate that the validation logic is out of date.

items.name: Insufficient Isolation of System-Dependent Functions
items.summary: The product or code does not isolate system-dependent functionality into separate standalone modules.

items.name: Reliance on Runtime Component in Generated Code
items.summary: The product uses automatically-generated code that cannot be executed without a specific runtime support component.

items.name: Reliance on Machine-Dependent Data Representation
items.summary: The code uses a data representation that relies on low-level data representation or constructs that may vary across different processors, physical machines, OSes, or other physical components.

items.name: Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components
items.summary: The product relies on third-party components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms.

items.name: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components
items.summary: The product relies on third-party components that are not actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy for the original developer.

items.name: Insufficient Encapsulation of Machine-Dependent Functionality
items.summary: The product or code uses machine-dependent functionality, but it does not sufficiently encapsulate or isolate this functionality from the rest of the code.

items.name: Insufficient Use of Symbolic Constants
items.summary: The source code uses literal constants that may need to change or evolve over time, instead of using symbolic constants.

items.name: Insufficient Isolation of Symbolic Constant Definitions
items.summary: The source code uses symbolic constants, but it does not sufficiently place the definitions of these constants into a more centralized or isolated location.

items.name: Excessive Reliance on Global Variables
items.summary: The code is structured in a way that relies too much on using or setting global variables throughout various points in the code, instead of preserving the associated information in a narrower, more local context.

items.name: Use of Same Variable for Multiple Purposes
items.summary: The code contains a callable, block, or other code element in which the same variable is used to control more than one unique task or store more than one instance of data.

items.name: Direct Use of Unsafe JNI
items.summary: When a Java application uses the Java Native Interface (JNI) to call code written in another programming language, it can expose the application to weaknesses in that code, even if those weaknesses cannot occur in Java.

items.name: Incomplete Design Documentation
items.summary: The product's design documentation does not adequately describe control flow, data flow, system initialization, relationships between tasks, components, rationales, or other important aspects of the design.

items.name: Incomplete I/O Documentation
items.summary: The product's documentation does not adequately define inputs, outputs, or system/software interfaces.

items.name: Incomplete Documentation of Program Execution
items.summary: The document does not fully define all mechanisms that are used to control or influence how product-specific programs are executed.

items.name: Inappropriate Comment Style
items.summary: The source code uses comment styles or formats that are inconsistent or do not follow expected standards for the product.

items.name: Inappropriate Whitespace Style
items.summary: The source code contains whitespace that is inconsistent across the code or does not follow expected standards for the product.

items.name: Source Code Element without Standard Prologue
items.summary: The source code contains elements such as source files that do not consistently provide a prologue or header that has been standardized for the project.

items.name: Inaccurate Source Code Comments
items.summary: The source code contains comments that do not accurately describe or explain aspects of the portion of the code with which the comment is associated.

items.name: Callable with Insufficient Behavioral Summary
items.summary: The code contains a function or method whose signature and/or associated inline documentation does not sufficiently describe the callable's inputs, outputs, side effects, assumptions, or return codes.

items.name: Insufficient Documentation of Error Handling Techniques
items.summary: The documentation does not sufficiently describe the techniques that are used for error handling, exception processing, or similar mechanisms.

items.name: Excessive Use of Unconditional Branching
items.summary: The code uses too many unconditional branches (such as "goto").

items.name: Missing XML Validation
items.summary: The product accepts XML from an untrusted source but does not validate the XML against the proper schema.

items.name: Excessive Code Complexity
items.summary: The code is too complex, as calculated using a well-defined, quantitative measure.

items.name: Excessive McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity
items.summary: The code contains McCabe cyclomatic complexity that exceeds a desirable maximum.

items.name: Excessive Halstead Complexity
items.summary: The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

items.name: Excessive Use of Self-Modifying Code
items.summary: The product uses too much self-modifying code.

items.name: Excessively Deep Nesting
items.summary: The code contains a callable or other code grouping in which the nesting / branching is too deep.

items.name: Excessive Attack Surface
items.summary: The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

items.name: Declaration of Variable with Unnecessarily Wide Scope
items.summary: The source code declares a variable in one scope, but the variable is only used within a narrower scope.

items.name: Compilation with Insufficient Warnings or Errors
items.summary: The code is compiled without sufficient warnings enabled, which may prevent the detection of subtle bugs or quality issues.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Request/Response Splitting')
items.summary: The product receives data from an HTTP agent/component (e.g., web server, proxy, browser, etc.), but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CR and LF characters before the data is included in outgoing HTTP headers.

items.name: Process Control
items.summary: Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker.

items.name: Misinterpretation of Input
items.summary: The product misinterprets an input, whether from an attacker or another product, in a security-relevant fashion.

items.name: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output
items.summary: The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

items.name: Irrelevant Code
items.summary: The product contains code that is not essential for execution, i.e. makes no state changes and has no side effects that alter data or control flow, such that removal of the code would have no impact to functionality or correctness.

items.name: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
items.summary: The product constructs a log message from external input, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements when the message is written to a log file.

items.name: Improper Use of Validation Framework
items.summary: The product does not use, or incorrectly uses, an input validation framework that is provided by the source language or an independent library.

items.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Improper Model Validation
items.summary: The ASP.NET application does not use, or incorrectly uses, the model validation framework.

items.name: Inefficient CPU Computation
items.summary: The product performs CPU computations using algorithms that are not as efficient as they could be for the needs of the developer, i.e., the computations can be optimized further.

items.name: Use of Prohibited Code
items.summary: The product uses a function, library, or third party component that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or the customer.

items.name: Incorrect Access of Indexable Resource ('Range Error')
items.summary: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts operations within the boundaries of a resource that is accessed using an index or pointer, such as memory or files.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Use of Uninitialized Resource
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-908. All content has been transferred to CWE-908.

items.name: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default
items.summary: The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the product's installer, administrator, or maintainer, but the default is not secure.

items.name: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)
items.summary: The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents.

items.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer
items.summary: The product performs operations on a memory buffer, but it reads from or writes to a memory location outside the buffer's intended boundary. This may result in read or write operations on unexpected memory locations that could be linked to other variables, data structures, or internal program data.

items.name: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase
items.summary: The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

items.name: On-Chip Debug and Test Interface With Improper Access Control
items.summary: The chip does not implement or does not correctly perform access control to check whether users are authorized to access internal registers and test modes through the physical debug/test interface.

items.name: Improper Identifier for IP Block used in System-On-Chip (SOC)
items.summary: The System-on-Chip (SoC) does not have unique, immutable identifiers for each of its components.

items.name: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control
items.summary: The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

items.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
items.summary: An ASP .NET application must enable custom error pages in order to prevent attackers from mining information from the framework's built-in responses.

items.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')
items.summary: The product copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer.

items.name: Generation of Weak Initialization Vector (IV)
items.summary: The product uses a cryptographic primitive that uses an Initialization Vector (IV), but the product does not generate IVs that are sufficiently unpredictable or unique according to the expected cryptographic requirements for that primitive.

items.name: Failure to Disable Reserved Bits
items.summary: The reserved bits in a hardware design are not disabled prior to production. Typically, reserved bits are used for future capabilities and should not support any functional logic in the design. However, designers might covertly use these bits to debug or further develop new capabilities in production hardware. Adversaries with access to these bits will write to them in hopes of compromising hardware state.

items.name: Stack-based Buffer Overflow
items.summary: A stack-based buffer overflow condition is a condition where the buffer being overwritten is allocated on the stack (i.e., is a local variable or, rarely, a parameter to a function).

items.name: Heap-based Buffer Overflow
items.summary: A heap overflow condition is a buffer overflow, where the buffer that can be overwritten is allocated in the heap portion of memory, generally meaning that the buffer was allocated using a routine such as malloc().

items.name: Insufficient Granularity of Access Control
items.summary: The product implements access controls via a policy or other feature with the intention to disable or restrict accesses (reads and/or writes) to assets in a system from untrusted agents. However, implemented access controls lack required granularity, which renders the control policy too broad because it allows accesses from unauthorized agents to the security-sensitive assets.

items.name: Incorrect Register Defaults or Module Parameters
items.summary: Hardware description language code incorrectly defines register defaults or hardware Intellectual Property (IP) parameters to insecure values.

items.name: Insufficient Granularity of Address Regions Protected by Register Locks
items.summary: The product defines a large address region protected from modification by the same register lock control bit. This results in a conflict between the functional requirement that some addresses need to be writable by software during operation and the security requirement that the system configuration lock bit must be set during the boot process.

items.name: Race Condition for Write-Once Attributes
items.summary: A write-once register in hardware design is programmable by an untrusted software component earlier than the trusted software component, resulting in a race condition issue.

items.name: Improper Restriction of Write-Once Bit Fields
items.summary: The hardware design control register "sticky bits" or write-once bit fields are improperly implemented, such that they can be reprogrammed by software.

items.name: Creation of Emergent Resource
items.summary: The product manages resources or behaves in a way that indirectly creates a new, distinct resource that can be used by attackers in violation of the intended policy.

items.name: Write-what-where Condition
items.summary: Any condition where the attacker has the ability to write an arbitrary value to an arbitrary location, often as the result of a buffer overflow.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Metadata
items.summary: The product prevents direct access to a resource containing sensitive information, but it does not sufficiently limit access to metadata that is derived from the original, sensitive information.

items.name: Improper Prevention of Lock Bit Modification
items.summary: The product uses a trusted lock bit for restricting access to registers, address regions, or other resources, but the product does not prevent the value of the lock bit from being modified after it has been set.

items.name: Improper Lock Behavior After Power State Transition
items.summary: Register lock bit protection disables changes to system configuration once the bit is set. Some of the protected registers or lock bits become programmable after power state transitions (e.g., Entry and wake from low power sleep modes) causing the system configuration to be changeable.

items.name: Security-Sensitive Hardware Controls with Missing Lock Bit Protection
items.summary: The product uses a register lock bit protection mechanism, but it does not ensure that the lock bit prevents modification of system registers or controls that perform changes to important hardware system configuration.

items.name: Hardware Internal or Debug Modes Allow Override of Locks
items.summary: System configuration protection may be bypassed during debug mode.

items.name: Incorrect Use of Autoboxing and Unboxing for Performance Critical Operations
items.summary: The code uses boxed primitives, which may introduce inefficiencies into performance-critical operations.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Formula Elements in a CSV File
items.summary: The product saves user-provided information into a Comma-Separated Value (CSV) file, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as a command when the file is opened by a spreadsheet product.

items.name: Improper Zeroization of Hardware Register
items.summary: The hardware product does not properly clear sensitive information from built-in registers when the user of the hardware block changes.

items.name: Buffer Underwrite ('Buffer Underflow')
items.summary: The product writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location prior to the beginning of the buffer.

items.name: Use of a Cryptographic Primitive with a Risky Implementation
items.summary: To fulfill the need for a cryptographic primitive, the product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard, unproven, or disallowed/non-compliant cryptographic implementation.

items.name: Use of Predictable Algorithm in Random Number Generator
items.summary: The device uses an algorithm that is predictable and generates a pseudo-random number.

items.name: Inclusion of Undocumented Features or Chicken Bits
items.summary: The device includes chicken bits or undocumented features that can create entry points for unauthorized actors.

items.name: Sensitive Non-Volatile Information Not Protected During Debug
items.summary: Access to security-sensitive information stored in fuses is not limited during debug.

items.name: Internal Asset Exposed to Unsafe Debug Access Level or State
items.summary: The product uses physical debug or test interfaces with support for multiple access levels, but it assigns the wrong debug access level to an internal asset, providing unintended access to the asset from untrusted debug agents.

items.name: Improper Finite State Machines (FSMs) in Hardware Logic
items.summary: Faulty finite state machines (FSMs) in the hardware logic allow an attacker to put the system in an undefined state, to cause a denial of service (DoS) or gain privileges on the victim's system.

items.name: Improper Write Handling in Limited-write Non-Volatile Memories
items.summary: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements wear leveling operations in limited-write non-volatile memories.

items.name: Improper Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches
items.summary: The device does not contain or contains incorrectly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device.

items.name: Semiconductor Defects in Hardware Logic with Security-Sensitive Implications
items.summary: The security-sensitive hardware module contains semiconductor defects.

items.name: Application-Level Admin Tool with Inconsistent View of Underlying Operating System
items.summary: The product provides an application for administrators to manage parts of the underlying operating system, but the application does not accurately identify all of the relevant entities or resources that exist in the OS; that is, the application's model of the OS's state is inconsistent with the OS's actual state.

items.name: Out-of-bounds Read
items.summary: The product reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer.

items.name: Improper Preservation of Consistency Between Independent Representations of Shared State
items.summary: The product has or supports multiple distributed components or sub-systems that are each required to keep their own local copy of shared data - such as state or cache - but the product does not ensure that all local copies remain consistent with each other.

items.name: Mirrored Regions with Different Values
items.summary: The product's architecture mirrors regions without ensuring that their contents always stay in sync.

items.name: CPU Hardware Not Configured to Support Exclusivity of Write and Execute Operations
items.summary: The CPU is not configured to provide hardware support for exclusivity of write and execute operations on memory. This allows an attacker to execute data from all of memory.

items.name: Incorrect Selection of Fuse Values
items.summary: The logic level used to set a system to a secure state relies on a fuse being unblown.

items.name: Incorrect Comparison Logic Granularity
items.summary: The product's comparison logic is performed over a series of steps rather than across the entire string in one operation. If there is a comparison logic failure on one of these steps, the operation may be vulnerable to a timing attack that can result in the interception of the process for nefarious purposes.

items.name: Comparison Logic is Vulnerable to Power Side-Channel Attacks
items.summary: A device's real time power consumption may be monitored during security token evaluation and the information gleaned may be used to determine the value of the reference token.

items.name: Improper Restriction of Software Interfaces to Hardware Features
items.summary: The product provides software-controllable device functionality for capabilities such as power and clock management, but it does not properly limit functionality that can lead to modification of hardware memory or register bits, or the ability to observe physical side channels.

items.name: Improper Access Control Applied to Mirrored or Aliased Memory Regions
items.summary: Aliased or mirrored memory regions in hardware designs may have inconsistent read/write permissions enforced by the hardware. A possible result is that an untrusted agent is blocked from accessing a memory region but is not blocked from accessing the corresponding aliased memory region.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information
items.summary: The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values, such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations, when debug mode is entered.

items.name: Improper Restriction of Security Token Assignment
items.summary: The System-On-A-Chip (SoC) implements a Security Token mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However, the Security Tokens are improperly protected.

items.name: Buffer Over-read
items.summary: The product reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations after the targeted buffer.

items.name: Improper Handling of Overlap Between Protected Memory Ranges
items.summary: The product allows address regions to overlap, which can result in the bypassing of intended memory protection.

items.name: Improper Handling of Single Event Upsets
items.summary: The hardware logic does not effectively handle when single-event upsets (SEUs) occur.

items.name: Improper Access Control for Register Interface
items.summary: The product uses memory-mapped I/O registers that act as an interface to hardware functionality from software, but there is improper access control to those registers.

items.name: Improper Physical Access Control
items.summary: The product is designed with access restricted to certain information, but it does not sufficiently protect against an unauthorized actor with physical access to these areas.

items.name: Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels
items.summary: The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete.

items.name: Unintended Reentrant Invocation of Non-reentrant Code Via Nested Calls
items.summary: The product invokes code that is believed to be reentrant, but the code performs a call that unintentionally produces a nested invocation of the non-reentrant code.

items.name: Improper Scrubbing of Sensitive Data from Decommissioned Device
items.summary: The product does not properly provide a capability for the product administrator to remove sensitive data at the time the product is decommissioned. A scrubbing capability could be missing, insufficient, or incorrect.

items.name: Policy Uses Obsolete Encoding
items.summary: The product uses an obsolete encoding mechanism to implement access controls.

items.name: Policy Privileges are not Assigned Consistently Between Control and Data Agents
items.summary: The product's hardware-enforced access control for a particular resource improperly accounts for privilege discrepancies between control and write policies.

items.name: Product Released in Non-Release Configuration
items.summary: The product released to market is released in pre-production or manufacturing configuration.

items.name: Buffer Under-read
items.summary: The product reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations prior to the targeted buffer.

items.name: Generation of Incorrect Security Tokens
items.summary: The product implements a Security Token mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However, the Security Tokens generated in the system are incorrect.

items.name: Uninitialized Value on Reset for Registers Holding Security Settings
items.summary: Security-critical logic is not set to a known value on reset.

items.name: Sensitive Information Uncleared Before Debug/Power State Transition
items.summary: The product performs a power or debug state transition, but it does not clear sensitive information that should no longer be accessible due to changes to information access restrictions.

items.name: Device Unlock Credential Sharing
items.summary: The credentials necessary for unlocking a device are shared across multiple parties and may expose sensitive information.

items.name: Improper Access Control for Volatile Memory Containing Boot Code
items.summary: The product conducts a secure-boot process that transfers bootloader code from Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) into Volatile Memory (VM), but it does not have sufficient access control or other protections for the Volatile Memory.

items.name: Sensitive Cookie with Improper SameSite Attribute
items.summary: The SameSite attribute for sensitive cookies is not set, or an insecure value is used.

items.name: Hardware Child Block Incorrectly Connected to Parent System
items.summary: Signals between a hardware IP and the parent system design are incorrectly connected causing security risks.

items.name: Firmware Not Updateable
items.summary: The product does not provide its users with the ability to update or patch its firmware to address any vulnerabilities or weaknesses that may be present.

items.name: Missing Protection Against Hardware Reverse Engineering Using Integrated Circuit (IC) Imaging Techniques
items.summary: Information stored in hardware may be recovered by an attacker with the capability to capture and analyze images of the integrated circuit using techniques such as scanning electron microscopy.

items.name: Cryptographic Operations are run Before Supporting Units are Ready
items.summary: Performing cryptographic operations without ensuring that the supporting inputs are ready to supply valid data may compromise the cryptographic result.

items.name: Wrap-around Error
items.summary: Wrap around errors occur whenever a value is incremented past the maximum value for its type and therefore "wraps around" to a very small, negative, or undefined value.

items.name: Access Control Check Implemented After Asset is Accessed
items.summary: A product's hardware-based access control check occurs after the asset has been accessed.

items.name: Sequence of Processor Instructions Leads to Unexpected Behavior
items.summary: Specific combinations of processor instructions lead to undesirable behavior such as locking the processor until a hard reset performed.

items.name: Assumed-Immutable Data is Stored in Writable Memory
items.summary: Immutable data, such as a first-stage bootloader, device identifiers, and "write-once" configuration settings are stored in writable memory that can be re-programmed or updated in the field.

items.name: Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data
items.summary: The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

items.name: Improper Validation of Specified Quantity in Input
items.summary: The product receives input that is expected to specify a quantity (such as size or length), but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the quantity has the required properties.

items.name: Improper Validation of Specified Index, Position, or Offset in Input
items.summary: The product receives input that is expected to specify an index, position, or offset into an indexable resource such as a buffer or file, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the specified index/position/offset has the required properties.

items.name: Improper Validation of Syntactic Correctness of Input
items.summary: The product receives input that is expected to be well-formed - i.e., to comply with a certain syntax - but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input complies with the syntax.

items.name: Improper Validation of Specified Type of Input
items.summary: The product receives input that is expected to be of a certain type, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is actually of the expected type.

items.name: Improper Validation of Consistency within Input
items.summary: The product receives a complex input with multiple elements or fields that must be consistent with each other, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is actually consistent.

items.name: Improper Validation of Unsafe Equivalence in Input
items.summary: The product receives an input value that is used as a resource identifier or other type of reference, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is equivalent to a potentially-unsafe value.

items.name: Improper Validation of Array Index
items.summary: The product uses untrusted input when calculating or using an array index, but the product does not validate or incorrectly validates the index to ensure the index references a valid position within the array.

items.name: Incorrect Decoding of Security Identifiers
items.summary: The product implements a decoding mechanism to decode certain bus-transaction signals to security identifiers. If the decoding is implemented incorrectly, then untrusted agents can now gain unauthorized access to the asset.

items.name: Public Key Re-Use for Signing both Debug and Production Code
items.summary: The same public key is used for signing both debug and production code.

items.name: Incorrect Conversion of Security Identifiers
items.summary: The product implements a conversion mechanism to map certain bus-transaction signals to security identifiers. However, if the conversion is incorrectly implemented, untrusted agents can gain unauthorized access to the asset.

items.name: Missing Source Correlation of Multiple Independent Data
items.summary: The product relies on one source of data, preventing the ability to detect if an adversary has compromised a data source.

items.name: Insecure Security Identifier Mechanism
items.summary: The System-on-Chip (SoC) implements a Security Identifier mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However, the Security Identifiers are not correctly implemented.

items.name: Debug Messages Revealing Unnecessary Information
items.summary: The product fails to adequately prevent the revealing of unnecessary and potentially sensitive system information within debugging messages.

items.name: Incorrect Chaining or Granularity of Debug Components
items.summary: The product's debug components contain incorrect chaining or granularity of debug components.

items.name: Unprotected Confidential Information on Device is Accessible by OSAT Vendors
items.summary: The product does not adequately protect confidential information on the device from being accessed by Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test (OSAT) vendors.

items.name: Hardware Logic Contains Race Conditions
items.summary: A race condition in the hardware logic results in undermining security guarantees of the system.

items.name: Missing Protection Mechanism for Alternate Hardware Interface
items.summary: The lack of protections on alternate paths to access control-protected assets (such as unprotected shadow registers and other external facing unguarded interfaces) allows an attacker to bypass existing protections to the asset that are only performed against the primary path.

items.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Password in Configuration File
items.summary: Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource making them an easy target for attackers.

items.name: Improper Handling of Length Parameter Inconsistency
items.summary: The product parses a formatted message or structure, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a length field that is inconsistent with the actual length of the associated data.

items.name: Improper Protection of Physical Side Channels
items.summary: The device does not contain sufficient protection mechanisms to prevent physical side channels from exposing sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable phenomena such as variations in power consumption, electromagnetic emissions (EME), or acoustic emissions.

items.name: Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component
items.summary: The product's data removal process does not completely delete all data and potentially sensitive information within hardware components.

items.name: Missing Source Identifier in Entity Transactions on a System-On-Chip (SOC)
items.summary: The product implements a security identifier mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. A transaction is sent without a security identifier.

items.name: Non-Transparent Sharing of Microarchitectural Resources
items.summary: Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g., caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts.

items.name: Improperly Preserved Integrity of Hardware Configuration State During a Power Save/Restore Operation
items.summary: The product performs a power save/restore operation, but it does not ensure that the integrity of the configuration state is maintained and/or verified between the beginning and ending of the operation.

items.name: Incorrect Calculation of Buffer Size
items.summary: The product does not correctly calculate the size to be used when allocating a buffer, which could lead to a buffer overflow.

items.name: Missing Ability to Patch ROM Code
items.summary: Missing an ability to patch ROM code may leave a System or System-on-Chip (SoC) in a vulnerable state.

items.name: Improper Translation of Security Attributes by Fabric Bridge
items.summary: The bridge incorrectly translates security attributes from either trusted to untrusted or from untrusted to trusted when converting from one fabric protocol to another.

items.name: Missing Protection for Mirrored Regions in On-Chip Fabric Firewall
items.summary: The firewall in an on-chip fabric protects the main addressed region, but it does not protect any mirrored memory or memory-mapped-IO (MMIO) regions.

items.name: Hardware Allows Activation of Test or Debug Logic at Runtime
items.summary: During runtime, the hardware allows for test or debug logic (feature) to be activated, which allows for changing the state of the hardware. This feature can alter the intended behavior of the system and allow for alteration and leakage of sensitive data by an adversary.

items.name: Missing Write Protection for Parametric Data Values
items.summary: The device does not write-protect the parametric data values for sensors that scale the sensor value, allowing untrusted software to manipulate the apparent result and potentially damage hardware or cause operational failure.

items.name: Improper Setting of Bus Controlling Capability in Fabric End-point
items.summary: The bus controller enables bits in the fabric end-point to allow responder devices to control transactions on the fabric.

items.name: Fabric-Address Map Allows Programming of Unwarranted Overlaps of Protected and Unprotected Ranges
items.summary: The address map of the on-chip fabric has protected and unprotected regions overlapping, allowing an attacker to bypass access control to the overlapping portion of the protected region.

items.name: Improper Access Control in Fabric Bridge
items.summary: The product uses a fabric bridge for transactions between two Intellectual Property (IP) blocks, but the bridge does not properly perform the expected privilege, identity, or other access control checks between those IP blocks.

items.name: Missing Support for Security Features in On-chip Fabrics or Buses
items.summary: On-chip fabrics or buses either do not support or are not configured to support privilege separation or other security features, such as access control.

items.name: Improper Protection against Electromagnetic Fault Injection (EM-FI)
items.summary: The device is susceptible to electromagnetic fault injection attacks, causing device internal information to be compromised or security mechanisms to be bypassed.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Miscalculated Null Termination
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-170. All content has been transferred to CWE-170.

items.name: Improper Protection for Outbound Error Messages and Alert Signals
items.summary: Untrusted agents can disable alerts about signal conditions exceeding limits or the response mechanism that handles such alerts.

items.name: Improperly Controlled Modification of Object Prototype Attributes ('Prototype Pollution')
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies attributes that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control modifications of attributes of the object prototype.

items.name: Use of Blocking Code in Single-threaded, Non-blocking Context
items.summary: The product uses a non-blocking model that relies on a single threaded process for features such as scalability, but it contains code that can block when it is invoked.

items.name: Improper Management of Sensitive Trace Data
items.summary: Trace data collected from several sources on the System-on-Chip (SoC) is stored in unprotected locations or transported to untrusted agents.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Sensitive Information Accessible by Physical Probing of JTAG Interface
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was at a lower level of abstraction than supported by CWE. All relevant content has been integrated into CWE-319.

items.name: Improperly Controlled Sequential Memory Allocation
items.summary: The product manages a group of objects or resources and performs a separate memory allocation for each object, but it does not properly limit the total amount of memory that is consumed by all of the combined objects.

items.name: Missing Immutable Root of Trust in Hardware
items.summary: A missing immutable root of trust in the hardware results in the ability to bypass secure boot or execute untrusted or adversarial boot code.

items.name: Binding to an Unrestricted IP Address
items.summary: The product assigns the address 0.0.0.0 for a database server, a cloud service/instance, or any computing resource that communicates remotely.

items.name: Security Version Number Mutable to Older Versions
items.summary: Security-version number in hardware is mutable, resulting in the ability to downgrade (roll-back) the boot firmware to vulnerable code versions.

items.name: Reliance on Component That is Not Updateable
items.summary: The product contains a component that cannot be updated or patched in order to remove vulnerabilities or significant bugs.

items.name: Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase
items.summary: Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased.

items.name: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)
items.summary: The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents, creating timing channels.

items.name: Improper Handling of Faults that Lead to Instruction Skips
items.summary: The device is missing or incorrectly implements circuitry or sensors that detect and mitigate the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions when they occur.

items.name: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity
items.summary: The product uses a regular expression with an inefficient, possibly exponential worst-case computational complexity that consumes excessive CPU cycles.

items.name: Unauthorized Error Injection Can Degrade Hardware Redundancy
items.summary: An unauthorized agent can inject errors into a redundant block to deprive the system of redundancy or put the system in a degraded operating mode.

items.name: Incorrect Bitwise Shift of Integer
items.summary: An integer value is specified to be shifted by a negative amount or an amount greater than or equal to the number of bits contained in the value causing an unexpected or indeterminate result.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements Used in a Template Engine
items.summary: The product uses a template engine to insert or process externally-influenced input, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements or syntax that can be interpreted as template expressions or other code directives when processed by the engine.

items.name: Improper Protections Against Hardware Overheating
items.summary: A hardware device is missing or has inadequate protection features to prevent overheating.

items.name: Insufficient Precision or Accuracy of a Real Number
items.summary: The product processes a real number with an implementation in which the number's representation does not preserve required accuracy and precision in its fractional part, causing an incorrect result.

items.name: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
items.summary: The product uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

items.name: Multiple Releases of Same Resource or Handle
items.summary: The product attempts to close or release a resource or handle more than once, without any successful open between the close operations.

items.name: Information Exposure through Microarchitectural State after Transient Execution
items.summary: The processor does not properly clear microarchitectural state after incorrect microcode assists or speculative execution, resulting in transient execution.

items.name: Incorrect Calculation of Multi-Byte String Length
items.summary: The product does not correctly calculate the length of strings that can contain wide or multi-byte characters.

items.name: Improper Handling of Hardware Behavior in Exceptionally Cold Environments
items.summary: A hardware device, or the firmware running on it, is missing or has incorrect protection features to maintain goals of security primitives when the device is cooled below standard operating temperatures.

items.name: Reliance on Insufficiently Trustworthy Component
items.summary: The product is built from multiple separate components, but it uses a component that is not sufficiently trusted to meet expectations for security, reliability, updateability, and maintainability.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as control elements or syntactic markers when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Handling of Physical or Environmental Conditions
items.summary: The product does not properly handle unexpected physical or environmental conditions that occur naturally or are artificially induced.

items.name: Missing Origin Validation in WebSockets
items.summary: The product uses a WebSocket, but it does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

items.name: Insecure Operation on Windows Junction / Mount Point
items.summary: The product opens a file or directory, but it does not properly prevent the name from being associated with a junction or mount point to a destination that is outside of the intended control sphere.

items.name: Incorrect Parsing of Numbers with Different Radices
items.summary: The product parses numeric input assuming base 10 (decimal) values, but it does not account for inputs that use a different base number (radix).

items.name: Weak Authentication
items.summary: The product uses an authentication mechanism to restrict access to specific users or identities, but the mechanism does not sufficiently prove that the claimed identity is correct.

items.name: Use of Weak Credentials
items.summary: The product uses weak credentials (such as a default key or hard-coded password) that can be calculated, derived, reused, or guessed by an attacker.

items.name: Use of Default Credentials
items.summary: The product uses default credentials (such as passwords or cryptographic keys) for potentially critical functionality.

items.name: Use of Default Password
items.summary: The product uses default passwords for potentially critical functionality.

items.name: Use of Default Cryptographic Key
items.summary: The product uses a default cryptographic key for potentially critical functionality.

items.name: Dependency on Vulnerable Third-Party Component
items.summary: The product has a dependency on a third-party component that contains one or more known vulnerabilities.

items.name: Compiler Removal of Code to Clear Buffers
items.summary: Sensitive memory is cleared according to the source code, but compiler optimizations leave the memory untouched when it is not read from again, aka "dead store removal."

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Delimiters
items.summary: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes delimiters.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Parameter/Argument Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as parameter or argument delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Incorrect Initialization of Resource
items.summary: The product attempts to initialize a resource but does not correctly do so, which might leave the resource in an unexpected, incorrect, or insecure state when it is accessed.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Value Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as value delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information during Transient Execution
items.summary: A processor event or prediction may allow incorrect operations (or correct operations with incorrect data) to execute transiently, potentially exposing data over a covert channel.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information in Shared Microarchitectural Structures during Transient Execution
items.summary: A processor event may allow transient operations to access architecturally restricted data (for example, in another address space) in a shared microarchitectural structure (for example, a CPU cache), potentially exposing the data over a covert channel.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information caused by Incorrect Data Forwarding during Transient Execution
items.summary: A processor event or prediction may allow incorrect or stale data to be forwarded to transient operations, potentially exposing data over a covert channel.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information caused by Shared Microarchitectural Predictor State that Influences Transient Execution
items.summary: Shared microarchitectural predictor state may allow code to influence transient execution across a hardware boundary, potentially exposing data that is accessible beyond the boundary over a covert channel.

items.name: Improper Validation of Generative AI Output
items.summary: The product invokes a generative AI/ML component whose behaviors and outputs cannot be directly controlled, but the product does not validate or insufficiently validates the outputs to ensure that they align with the intended security, content, or privacy policy.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Input Used for LLM Prompting
items.summary: The product uses externally-provided data to build prompts provided to large language models (LLMs), but the way these prompts are constructed causes the LLM to fail to distinguish between user-supplied inputs and developer provided system directives.

items.name: Reliance on HTTP instead of HTTPS
items.summary: The product provides or relies on use of HTTP communications when HTTPS is available.

items.name: Missing Security-Relevant Feedback for Unexecuted Operations in Hardware Interface
items.summary: The product has a hardware interface that silently discards operations in situations for which feedback would be security-relevant, such as the timely detection of failures or attacks.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Record Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as record delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Driving Intermediate Cryptographic State/Results to Hardware Module Outputs
items.summary: The product uses a hardware module implementing a cryptographic algorithm that writes sensitive information about the intermediate state or results of its cryptographic operations via one of its output wires (typically the output port containing the final result).

items.name: Insecure Setting of Generative AI/ML Model Inference Parameters
items.summary: The product has a component that relies on a generative AI/ML model configured with inference parameters that produce an unacceptably high rate of erroneous or unexpected outputs.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Line Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as line delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Section Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as section delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Expression/Command Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as expression or command delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Input Terminators
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as input terminators when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Input Leaders
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when a leading character or sequence ("leader") is missing or malformed, or if multiple leaders are used when only one should be allowed.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Quoting Syntax
items.summary: Quotes injected into a product can be used to compromise a system. As data are parsed, an injected/absent/duplicate/malformed use of quotes may cause the process to take unexpected actions.

items.name: External Control of System or Configuration Setting
items.summary: One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Escape, Meta, or Control Sequences
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as escape, meta, or control character sequences when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Comment Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as comment delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Macro Symbols
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as macro symbols when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Substitution Characters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as substitution characters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Variable Name Delimiters
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as variable name delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Wildcards or Matching Symbols
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as wildcards or matching symbols when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Whitespace
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as whitespace when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Failure to Sanitize Paired Delimiters
items.summary: The product does not properly handle the characters that are used to mark the beginning and ending of a group of entities, such as parentheses, brackets, and braces.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Null Byte or NUL Character
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes NUL characters or null bytes when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Handling of Invalid Use of Special Elements
items.summary: The product does not properly filter, remove, quote, or otherwise manage the invalid use of special elements in user-controlled input, which could cause adverse effect on its behavior and integrity.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Leading Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes leading special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Leading Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple leading special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Trailing Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes trailing special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Trailing Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple trailing special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Internal Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes internal special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Internal Special Elements
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple internal special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

items.name: Improper Handling of Missing Special Element
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an expected special element is missing.

items.name: Improper Handling of Additional Special Element
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an additional unexpected special element is provided.

items.name: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Special Elements
items.summary: The product does not properly handle input in which an inconsistency exists between two or more special characters or reserved words.

items.name: Improper Null Termination
items.summary: The product does not terminate or incorrectly terminates a string or array with a null character or equivalent terminator.

items.name: Encoding Error
items.summary: The product does not properly encode or decode the data, resulting in unexpected values.

items.name: Improper Handling of Alternate Encoding
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when an input uses an alternate encoding that is valid for the control sphere to which the input is being sent.

items.name: Double Decoding of the Same Data
items.summary: The product decodes the same input twice, which can limit the effectiveness of any protection mechanism that occurs in between the decoding operations.

items.name: Improper Handling of Mixed Encoding
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when the same input uses several different (mixed) encodings.

items.name: Improper Handling of Unicode Encoding
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when an input contains Unicode encoding.

items.name: Improper Handling of URL Encoding (Hex Encoding)
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when all or part of an input has been URL encoded.

items.name: Improper Handling of Case Sensitivity
items.summary: The product does not properly account for differences in case sensitivity when accessing or determining the properties of a resource, leading to inconsistent results.

items.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Validation
items.summary: The product validates input before applying protection mechanisms that modify the input, which could allow an attacker to bypass the validation via dangerous inputs that only arise after the modification.

items.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Validate Before Canonicalize
items.summary: The product validates input before it is canonicalized, which prevents the product from detecting data that becomes invalid after the canonicalization step.

items.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Validate Before Filter
items.summary: The product validates data before it has been filtered, which prevents the product from detecting data that becomes invalid after the filtering step.

items.name: Collapse of Data into Unsafe Value
items.summary: The product filters data in a way that causes it to be reduced or "collapsed" into an unsafe value that violates an expected security property.

items.name: Permissive List of Allowed Inputs
items.summary: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are explicitly allowed by policy because the inputs are assumed to be safe, but the list is too permissive - that is, it allows an input that is unsafe, leading to resultant weaknesses.

items.name: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs
items.summary: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete.

items.name: Incorrect Regular Expression
items.summary: The product specifies a regular expression in a way that causes data to be improperly matched or compared.

items.name: Overly Restrictive Regular Expression
items.summary: A regular expression is overly restrictive, which prevents dangerous values from being detected.

items.name: Partial String Comparison
items.summary: The product performs a comparison that only examines a portion of a factor before determining whether there is a match, such as a substring, leading to resultant weaknesses.

items.name: Reliance on Data/Memory Layout
items.summary: The product makes invalid assumptions about how protocol data or memory is organized at a lower level, resulting in unintended program behavior.

items.name: Integer Overflow or Wraparound
