items.summary: The product performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This occurs when an integer value is incremented to a value that is too large to store in the associated representation. When this occurs, the value may become a very small or negative number.

items.name: Integer Underflow (Wrap or Wraparound)
items.summary: The product subtracts one value from another, such that the result is less than the minimum allowable integer value, which produces a value that is not equal to the correct result.

items.name: Integer Coercion Error
items.summary: Integer coercion refers to a set of flaws pertaining to the type casting, extension, or truncation of primitive data types.

items.name: Off-by-one Error
items.summary: A product calculates or uses an incorrect maximum or minimum value that is 1 more, or 1 less, than the correct value.

items.name: Unexpected Sign Extension
items.summary: The product performs an operation on a number that causes it to be sign extended when it is transformed into a larger data type. When the original number is negative, this can produce unexpected values that lead to resultant weaknesses.

items.name: Signed to Unsigned Conversion Error
items.summary: The product uses a signed primitive and performs a cast to an unsigned primitive, which can produce an unexpected value if the value of the signed primitive can not be represented using an unsigned primitive.

items.name: Unsigned to Signed Conversion Error
items.summary: The product uses an unsigned primitive and performs a cast to a signed primitive, which can produce an unexpected value if the value of the unsigned primitive can not be represented using a signed primitive.

items.name: Numeric Truncation Error
items.summary: Truncation errors occur when a primitive is cast to a primitive of a smaller size and data is lost in the conversion.

items.name: Use of Incorrect Byte Ordering
items.summary: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not account for byte ordering (e.g. big-endian and little-endian) when processing the input, causing an incorrect number or value to be used.

items.name: Improper Input Validation
items.summary: The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
items.summary: The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

items.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Sent Data
items.summary: The code transmits data to another actor, but a portion of the data includes sensitive information that should not be accessible to that actor.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Data Queries
items.summary: When trying to keep information confidential, an attacker can often infer some of the information by using statistics.

items.name: Observable Discrepancy
items.summary: The product behaves differently or sends different responses under different circumstances in a way that is observable to an unauthorized actor, which exposes security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.

items.name: Observable Response Discrepancy
items.summary: The product provides different responses to incoming requests in a way that reveals internal state information to an unauthorized actor outside of the intended control sphere.

items.name: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy
items.summary: The product's behaviors indicate important differences that may be observed by unauthorized actors in a way that reveals (1) its internal state or decision process, or (2) differences from other products with equivalent functionality.

items.name: Observable Internal Behavioral Discrepancy
items.summary: The product performs multiple behaviors that are combined to produce a single result, but the individual behaviors are observable separately in a way that allows attackers to reveal internal state or internal decision points.

items.name: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy With Equivalent Products
items.summary: The product operates in an environment in which its existence or specific identity should not be known, but it behaves differently than other products with equivalent functionality, in a way that is observable to an attacker.

items.name: Observable Timing Discrepancy
items.summary: Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete, in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.

items.name: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

items.name: Self-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The product identifies an error condition and creates its own diagnostic or error messages that contain sensitive information.

items.name: Externally-Generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The product performs an operation that triggers an external diagnostic or error message that is not directly generated or controlled by the product, such as an error generated by the programming language interpreter that a software application uses. The error can contain sensitive system information.

items.name: Improper Removal of Sensitive Information Before Storage or Transfer
items.summary: The product stores, transfers, or shares a resource that contains sensitive information, but it does not properly remove that information before the product makes the resource available to unauthorized actors.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information Due to Incompatible Policies
items.summary: The product's intended functionality exposes information to certain actors in accordance with the developer's security policy, but this information is regarded as sensitive according to the intended security policies of other stakeholders such as the product's administrator, users, or others whose information is being processed.

items.name: Invocation of Process Using Visible Sensitive Information
items.summary: A process is invoked with sensitive command-line arguments, environment variables, or other elements that can be seen by other processes on the operating system.

items.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code
items.summary: The product inserts sensitive information into debugging code, which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Containment Errors (Container Errors)
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated, as it was not effective as a weakness and was structured more like a category. In addition, the name is inappropriate, since the "container" term is widely understood by developers in different ways than originally intended by PLOVER, the original source for this entry.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Failure to Protect Stored Data from Modification
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it incorporated and confused multiple weaknesses. The issues formerly covered in this entry can be found at CWE-766 and CWE-767.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Failure to provide confidentiality for stored data
items.summary: This weakness has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-493. All content has been transferred to CWE-493.

items.name: Storage of File with Sensitive Data Under Web Root
items.summary: The product stores sensitive data under the web document root with insufficient access control, which might make it accessible to untrusted parties.

items.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the product does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.

items.name: Storage of File With Sensitive Data Under FTP Root
items.summary: The product stores sensitive data under the FTP server root with insufficient access control, which might make it accessible to untrusted parties.

items.name: Information Loss or Omission
items.summary: The product does not record, or improperly records, security-relevant information that leads to an incorrect decision or hampers later analysis.

items.name: Truncation of Security-relevant Information
items.summary: The product truncates the display, recording, or processing of security-relevant information in a way that can obscure the source or nature of an attack.

items.name: Omission of Security-relevant Information
items.summary: The product does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack, or determining if an action is safe.

items.name: Obscured Security-relevant Information by Alternate Name
items.summary: The product records security-relevant information according to an alternate name of the affected entity, instead of the canonical name.

items.name: DEPRECATED: General Information Management Problems
items.summary: This weakness can be found at CWE-199.

items.name: Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse
items.summary: The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse, but it does not clear or "zeroize" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities.

items.name: Improper Handling of Syntactically Invalid Structure
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles input that is not syntactically well-formed with respect to the associated specification.

items.name: Improper Handling of Values
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when the expected number of values for parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those values are undefined.

items.name: Relative Path Traversal
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as ".." that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Improper Handling of Missing Values
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a parameter, field, or argument name is specified, but the associated value is missing, i.e. it is empty, blank, or null.

items.name: Improper Handling of Extra Values
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when more values are provided than expected.

items.name: Improper Handling of Undefined Values
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a value is not defined or supported for the associated parameter, field, or argument name.

items.name: Improper Handling of Parameters
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those parameters are undefined.

items.name: Failure to Handle Missing Parameter
items.summary: If too few arguments are sent to a function, the function will still pop the expected number of arguments from the stack. Potentially, a variable number of arguments could be exhausted in a function as well.

items.name: Improper Handling of Extra Parameters
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when the number of parameters, fields, or arguments with the same name exceeds the expected amount.

items.name: Improper Handling of Undefined Parameters
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular parameter, field, or argument name is not defined or supported by the product.

items.name: Improper Handling of Structural Elements
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles inputs that are related to complex structures.

items.name: Improper Handling of Incomplete Structural Elements
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular structural element is not completely specified.

items.name: Failure to Handle Incomplete Element
items.summary: The product does not properly handle when a particular element is not completely specified.

items.name: Path Traversal: '../filedir'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Structural Elements
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when two or more structural elements should be consistent, but are not.

items.name: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular element is not the expected type, e.g. it expects a digit (0-9) but is provided with a letter (A-Z).

items.name: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function
items.summary: The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.

items.name: Creation of chroot Jail Without Changing Working Directory
items.summary: The product uses the chroot() system call to create a jail, but does not change the working directory afterward. This does not prevent access to files outside of the jail.

items.name: Improper Clearing of Heap Memory Before Release ('Heap Inspection')
items.summary: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.

items.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Management of Connections
items.summary: The J2EE application directly manages connections, instead of using the container's connection management facilities.

items.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Sockets
items.summary: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Reliance on DNS Lookups in a Security Decision
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.

items.name: Uncaught Exception
items.summary: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Often Misused: Path Manipulation
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because of name confusion and an accidental combination of multiple weaknesses. Most of its content has been transferred to CWE-785.

items.name: Path Traversal: '/../filedir'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
items.summary: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

items.name: Unchecked Return Value
items.summary: The product does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.

items.name: Incorrect Check of Function Return Value
items.summary: The product incorrectly checks a return value from a function, which prevents it from detecting errors or exceptional conditions.

items.name: Plaintext Storage of a Password
items.summary: The product stores a password in plaintext within resources such as memory or files.

items.name: Storing Passwords in a Recoverable Format
items.summary: The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact, it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly, or use a brute force search on the available information, the administrator can use the password on other acco

items.name: Empty Password in Configuration File
items.summary: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.

items.name: Use of Hard-coded Password
items.summary: The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

items.name: Path Traversal: '/dir/../filename'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/dir/../filename" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Password in Configuration File
items.summary: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.

items.name: Weak Encoding for Password
items.summary: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.

items.name: Not Using Password Aging
items.summary: The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging.

items.name: Password Aging with Long Expiration
items.summary: The product supports password aging, but the expiration period is too long.

items.name: Incorrect Privilege Assignment
items.summary: A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

items.name: Privilege Defined With Unsafe Actions
items.summary: A particular privilege, role, capability, or right can be used to perform unsafe actions that were not intended, even when it is assigned to the correct entity.

items.name: Privilege Chaining
items.summary: Two distinct privileges, roles, capabilities, or rights can be combined in a way that allows an entity to perform unsafe actions that would not be allowed without that combination.

items.name: Improper Privilege Management
items.summary: The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

items.name: Path Traversal: 'dir/../../filename'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Privilege Context Switching Error
items.summary: The product does not properly manage privileges while it is switching between different contexts that have different privileges or spheres of control.

items.name: Privilege Dropping / Lowering Errors
items.summary: The product does not drop privileges before passing control of a resource to an actor that does not have those privileges.

items.name: Least Privilege Violation
items.summary: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

items.name: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges
items.summary: The product attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded.

items.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Privileges
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to perform an operation, leading to resultant weaknesses.

items.name: Incorrect Default Permissions
items.summary: During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

items.name: Insecure Inherited Permissions
items.summary: A product defines a set of insecure permissions that are inherited by objects that are created by the program.

items.name: Insecure Preserved Inherited Permissions
items.summary: A product inherits a set of insecure permissions for an object, e.g. when copying from an archive file, without user awareness or involvement.

items.name: Incorrect Execution-Assigned Permissions
items.summary: While it is executing, the product sets the permissions of an object in a way that violates the intended permissions that have been specified by the user.

items.name: Path Traversal: '..\filedir'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "..\" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Permissions or Privileges
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to access resources or functionality as specified by their permissions. This may cause it to follow unexpected code paths that may leave the product in an invalid state.

items.name: Improper Preservation of Permissions
items.summary: The product does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.

items.name: Improper Ownership Management
items.summary: The product assigns the wrong ownership, or does not properly verify the ownership, of an object or resource.

items.name: Unverified Ownership
items.summary: The product does not properly verify that a critical resource is owned by the proper entity.

items.name: Improper Access Control
items.summary: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

items.name: Improper Authorization
items.summary: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

items.name: Incorrect User Management
items.summary: The product does not properly manage a user within its environment.

items.name: Improper Authentication
items.summary: When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

items.name: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel
items.summary: The product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.

items.name: Authentication Bypass by Alternate Name
items.summary: The product performs authentication based on the name of a resource being accessed, or the name of the actor performing the access, but it does not properly check all possible names for that resource or actor.

items.name: Path Traversal: '\..\filename'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Authentication Bypass by Spoofing
items.summary: This attack-focused weakness is caused by incorrectly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks.

items.name: Reliance on IP Address for Authentication
items.summary: The product uses an IP address for authentication.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Trusting Self-reported DNS Name
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.

items.name: Using Referer Field for Authentication
items.summary: The referer field in HTTP requests can be easily modified and, as such, is not a valid means of message integrity checking.

items.name: Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay
items.summary: A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).

items.name: Improper Certificate Validation
items.summary: The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.

items.name: Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust
items.summary: The product does not follow, or incorrectly follows, the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate, resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate.

items.name: Improper Validation of Certificate with Host Mismatch
items.summary: The product communicates with a host that provides a certificate, but the product does not properly ensure that the certificate is actually associated with that host.

items.name: Improper Validation of Certificate Expiration
items.summary: A certificate expiration is not validated or is incorrectly validated, so trust may be assigned to certificates that have been abandoned due to age.

items.name: Improper Check for Certificate Revocation
items.summary: The product does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate, which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised.

items.name: Path Traversal: '\dir\..\filename'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '\dir\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint
items.summary: The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint.

items.name: Reflection Attack in an Authentication Protocol
items.summary: Simple authentication protocols are subject to reflection attacks if a malicious user can use the target machine to impersonate a trusted user.

items.name: Authentication Bypass by Assumed-Immutable Data
items.summary: The authentication scheme or implementation uses key data elements that are assumed to be immutable, but can be controlled or modified by the attacker.

items.name: Incorrect Implementation of Authentication Algorithm
items.summary: The requirements for the product dictate the use of an established authentication algorithm, but the implementation of the algorithm is incorrect.

items.name: Missing Critical Step in Authentication
items.summary: The product implements an authentication technique, but it skips a step that weakens the technique.

items.name: Authentication Bypass by Primary Weakness
items.summary: The authentication algorithm is sound, but the implemented mechanism can be bypassed as the result of a separate weakness that is primary to the authentication error.

items.name: Missing Authentication for Critical Function
items.summary: The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

items.name: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts
items.summary: The product does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within a short time frame.

items.name: Use of Single-factor Authentication
items.summary: The product uses an authentication algorithm that uses a single factor (e.g., a password) in a security context that should require more than one factor.

items.name: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication
items.summary: The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings, each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

items.name: Path Traversal: 'dir\..\..\filename'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize 'dir\..\..\filename' (multiple internal backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
items.summary: The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission.

items.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

items.name: Cleartext Storage in a File or on Disk
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a file, or on disk.

items.name: Cleartext Storage in the Registry
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in the registry.

items.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a cookie.

items.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Memory
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in memory.

items.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in GUI
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within the GUI.

items.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Executable
items.summary: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in an executable.

items.name: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
items.summary: The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

items.name: Path Traversal: '...' (Triple Dot)
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '...' (triple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key
items.summary: The product uses a hard-coded, unchangeable cryptographic key.

items.name: Key Exchange without Entity Authentication
items.summary: The product performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor.

items.name: Reusing a Nonce, Key Pair in Encryption
items.summary: Nonces should be used for the present occasion and only once.

items.name: Use of a Key Past its Expiration Date
items.summary: The product uses a cryptographic key or password past its expiration date, which diminishes its safety significantly by increasing the timing window for cracking attacks against that key.

items.name: Missing Cryptographic Step
items.summary: The product does not implement a required step in a cryptographic algorithm, resulting in weaker encryption than advertised by the algorithm.

items.name: Inadequate Encryption Strength
items.summary: The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required.

items.name: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
items.summary: The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

items.name: Use of Weak Hash
items.summary: The product uses an algorithm that produces a digest (output value) that does not meet security expectations for a hash function that allows an adversary to reasonably determine the original input (preimage attack), find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack), or find multiple inputs that evaluate to the same hash (birthday attack).

items.name: Generation of Predictable IV with CBC Mode
items.summary: The product generates and uses a predictable initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode, which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key.

items.name: Path Traversal: '....' (Multiple Dot)
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '....' (multiple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
items.summary: The product uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

items.name: Insufficient Entropy
items.summary: The product uses an algorithm or scheme that produces insufficient entropy, leaving patterns or clusters of values that are more likely to occur than others.

items.name: Insufficient Entropy in PRNG
items.summary: The lack of entropy available for, or used by, a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) can be a stability and security threat.

items.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
items.summary: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block.

items.name: Small Space of Random Values
items.summary: The number of possible random values is smaller than needed by the product, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

items.name: Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
items.summary: The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) but does not correctly manage seeds.

items.name: Same Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
items.summary: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses the same seed each time the product is initialized.

items.name: Predictable Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
items.summary: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) is initialized from a predictable seed, such as the process ID or system time.

items.name: Use of Cryptographically Weak Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
items.summary: The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) in a security context, but the PRNG's algorithm is not cryptographically strong.

items.name: Small Seed Space in PRNG
items.summary: A Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) uses a relatively small seed space, which makes it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

items.name: Path Traversal: '....//'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '....//' (doubled dot dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Generation of Predictable Numbers or Identifiers
items.summary: The product uses a scheme that generates numbers or identifiers that are more predictable than required.

items.name: Predictable from Observable State
items.summary: A number or object is predictable based on observations that the attacker can make about the state of the system or network, such as time, process ID, etc.

items.name: Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values
items.summary: An exact value or random number can be precisely predicted by observing previous values.

items.name: Predictable Value Range from Previous Values
items.summary: The product's random number generator produces a series of values which, when observed, can be used to infer a relatively small range of possibilities for the next value that could be generated.

items.name: Use of Invariant Value in Dynamically Changing Context
items.summary: The product uses a constant value, name, or reference, but this value can (or should) vary across different environments.

items.name: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity
items.summary: The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

items.name: Origin Validation Error
items.summary: The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

items.name: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature
items.summary: The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

items.name: Use of Less Trusted Source
items.summary: The product has two different sources of the same data or information, but it uses the source that has less support for verification, is less trusted, or is less resistant to attack.

items.name: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data
items.summary: The product, when processing trusted data, accepts any untrusted data that is also included with the trusted data, treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

items.name: Path Traversal: '.../...//'
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '.../...//' (doubled triple dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Reliance on Reverse DNS Resolution for a Security-Critical Action
items.summary: The product performs reverse DNS resolution on an IP address to obtain the hostname and make a security decision, but it does not properly ensure that the IP address is truly associated with the hostname.

items.name: Insufficient Type Distinction
items.summary: The product does not properly distinguish between different types of elements in a way that leads to insecure behavior.

items.name: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
items.summary: The web application does not, or cannot, sufficiently verify whether a request was intentionally provided by the user who sent the request, which could have originated from an unauthorized actor.

items.name: Missing Support for Integrity Check
items.summary: The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum.

items.name: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value
items.summary: The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission.

items.name: Product UI does not Warn User of Unsafe Actions
items.summary: The product's user interface does not warn the user before undertaking an unsafe action on behalf of that user. This makes it easier for attackers to trick users into inflicting damage to their system.

items.name: Insufficient UI Warning of Dangerous Operations
items.summary: The user interface provides a warning to a user regarding dangerous or sensitive operations, but the warning is not noticeable enough to warrant attention.

items.name: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard
items.summary: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm, protocol, or technique.

items.name: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
items.summary: The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

items.name: Absolute Path Traversal
items.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize absolute path sequences such as "/abs/path" that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

items.name: Trust of System Event Data
items.summary: Security based on event locations are insecure and can be spoofed.

items.name: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')
items.summary: The product contains a concurrent code sequence that requires temporary, exclusive access to a shared resource, but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence operating concurrently.

items.name: Race Condition Enabling Link Following
items.summary: The product checks the status of a file or directory before accessing it, which produces a race condition in which the file can be replaced with a link before the access is performed, causing the product to access the wrong file.

items.name: Signal Handler Race Condition
items.summary: The product uses a signal handler that introduces a race condition.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Race Condition in Switch
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated. There are no documented cases in which a switch's control expression is evaluated more than once.

items.name: Race Condition within a Thread
items.summary: If two threads of execution use a resource simultaneously, there exists the possibility that resources may be used while invalid, in turn making the state of execution undefined.

items.name: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition
items.summary: The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource, but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check.

items.name: Context Switching Race Condition
items.summary: A product performs a series of non-atomic actions to switch between contexts that cross privilege or other security boundaries, but a race condition allows an attacker to modify or misrepresent the product's behavior during the switch.

items.name: Divide By Zero
items.summary: The product divides a value by zero.

items.name: Path Traversal: '/absolute/pathname/here'
items.summary: The product accepts input in the form of a slash absolute path ('/absolute/pathname/here') without appropriate validation, which can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Missing Check for Certificate Revocation after Initial Check
items.summary: The product does not check the revocation status of a certificate after its initial revocation check, which can cause the product to perform privileged actions even after the certificate is revoked at a later time.

items.name: Incomplete Internal State Distinction
items.summary: The product does not properly determine which state it is in, causing it to assume it is in state X when in fact it is in state Y, causing it to perform incorrect operations in a security-relevant manner.

items.name: DEPRECATED: State Synchronization Error
items.summary: This entry was deprecated because it overlapped the same concepts as race condition (CWE-362) and Improper Synchronization (CWE-662).

items.name: Passing Mutable Objects to an Untrusted Method
items.summary: The product sends non-cloned mutable data as an argument to a method or function.

items.name: Returning a Mutable Object to an Untrusted Caller
items.summary: Sending non-cloned mutable data as a return value may result in that data being altered or deleted by the calling function.

items.name: Insecure Temporary File
items.summary: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

items.name: Creation of Temporary File With Insecure Permissions
items.summary: Opening temporary files without appropriate measures or controls can leave the file, its contents and any function that it impacts vulnerable to attack.

items.name: Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions
items.summary: The product creates a temporary file in a directory whose permissions allow unintended actors to determine the file's existence or otherwise access that file.

items.name: Path Traversal: '\absolute\pathname\here'
items.summary: The product accepts input in the form of a backslash absolute path ('\absolute\pathname\here') without appropriate validation, which can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
items.summary: A J2EE application uses System.exit(), which also shuts down its container.

items.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
items.summary: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.

items.name: Session Fixation
items.summary: Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

items.name: Covert Timing Channel
items.summary: Covert timing channels convey information by modulating some aspect of system behavior over time, so that the program receiving the information can observe system behavior and infer protected information.

items.name: Symbolic Name not Mapping to Correct Object
items.summary: A constant symbolic reference to an object is used, even though the reference can resolve to a different object over time.

items.name: Path Traversal: 'C:dirname'
items.summary: The product accepts input that contains a drive letter or Windows volume letter ('C:dirname') that potentially redirects access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

items.name: Detection of Error Condition Without Action
items.summary: The product detects a specific error, but takes no actions to handle the error.

items.name: Unchecked Error Condition
items.summary: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES AND CONSIDER CWE-252, CWE-248, OR CWE-1069.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

items.name: Missing Report of Error Condition
items.summary: The product encounters an error but does not provide a status code or return value to indicate that an error has occurred.

items.name: Return of Wrong Status Code
items.summary: A function or operation returns an incorrect return value or status code that does not indicate the true result of execution, causing the product to modify its behavior based on the incorrect result.

items.name: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value
items.summary: The product does not properly check when a function or operation returns a value that is legitimate for the function, but is not expected by the product.

items.name: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
items.summary: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer.

items.name: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
items.summary: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

items.name: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
items.summary: The product throws or raises an overly broad exceptions that can hide important details and produce inappropriate responses to certain conditions.

items.name: Path Traversal: '\\UNC\share\name\' (Windows UNC Share)
items.summary: The product accepts input that identifies a Windows UNC share ('\\UNC\share\name') that potentially redirects access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

items.name: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
items.summary: The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource.

items.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
items.summary: The product does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used, making the memory unavailable for reallocation and reuse.

items.name: Transmission of Private Resources into a New Sphere ('Resource Leak')
items.summary: The product makes resources available to untrusted parties when those resources are only intended to be accessed by the product.

items.name: Exposure of File Descriptor to Unintended Control Sphere ('File Descriptor Leak')
items.summary: A process does not close sensitive file descriptors before invoking a child process, which allows the child to perform unauthorized I/O operations using those descriptors.

items.name: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release
items.summary: The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use.

items.name: Asymmetric Resource Consumption (Amplification)
items.summary: The product does not properly control situations in which an adversary can cause the product to consume or produce excessive resources without requiring the adversary to invest equivalent work or otherwise prove authorization, i.e., the adversary's influence is "asymmetric."

items.name: Insufficient Control of Network Message Volume (Network Amplification)
items.summary: The product does not sufficiently monitor or control transmitted network traffic volume, so that an actor can cause the product to transmit more traffic than should be allowed for that actor.

items.name: Inefficient Algorithmic Complexity
items.summary: An algorithm in a product has an inefficient worst-case computational complexity that may be detrimental to system performance and can be triggered by an attacker, typically using crafted manipulations that ensure that the worst case is being reached.

items.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Amplification
items.summary: The product allows an entity to perform a legitimate but expensive operation before authentication or authorization has taken place.

items.name: Improper Handling of Highly Compressed Data (Data Amplification)
items.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output.

items.name: Improper Resolution of Path Equivalence
items.summary: The product is vulnerable to file system contents disclosure through path equivalence. Path equivalence involves the use of special characters in file and directory names. The associated manipulations are intended to generate multiple names for the same object.

items.name: Insufficient Resource Pool
items.summary: The product's resource pool is not large enough to handle peak demand, which allows an attacker to prevent others from accessing the resource by using a (relatively) large number of requests for resources.

items.name: Unrestricted Externally Accessible Lock
items.summary: The product properly checks for the existence of a lock, but the lock can be externally controlled or influenced by an actor that is outside of the intended sphere of control.

items.name: Improper Resource Locking
items.summary: The product does not lock or does not correctly lock a resource when the product must have exclusive access to the resource.

items.name: Missing Lock Check
items.summary: A product does not check to see if a lock is present before performing sensitive operations on a resource.

items.name: Double Free
items.summary: The product calls free() twice on the same memory address.

items.name: Use After Free
items.summary: The product reuses or references memory after it has been freed. At some point afterward, the memory may be allocated again and saved in another pointer, while the original pointer references a location somewhere within the new allocation. Any operations using the original pointer are no longer valid because the memory "belongs" to the code that operates on the new pointer.

items.name: Unprotected Primary Channel
items.summary: The product uses a primary channel for administration or restricted functionality, but it does not properly protect the channel.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename.' (Trailing Dot)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing dot ('filedir.') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Unprotected Alternate Channel
items.summary: The product protects a primary channel, but it does not use the same level of protection for an alternate channel.

items.name: Race Condition During Access to Alternate Channel
items.summary: The product opens an alternate channel to communicate with an authorized user, but the channel is accessible to other actors.

items.name: Unprotected Windows Messaging Channel ('Shatter')
items.summary: The product does not properly verify the source of a message in the Windows Messaging System while running at elevated privileges, creating an alternate channel through which an attacker can directly send a message to the product.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Proxied Trusted Channel
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-441. All content has been transferred to CWE-441.

items.name: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
items.summary: The product does not sufficiently protect all possible paths that a user can take to access restricted functionality or resources.

items.name: Direct Request ('Forced Browsing')
items.summary: The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs, scripts, or files.

items.name: Untrusted Search Path
items.summary: The product searches for critical resources using an externally-supplied search path that can point to resources that are not under the product's direct control.

items.name: Uncontrolled Search Path Element
items.summary: The product uses a fixed or controlled search path to find resources, but one or more locations in that path can be under the control of unintended actors.

items.name: Unquoted Search Path or Element
items.summary: The product uses a search path that contains an unquoted element, in which the element contains whitespace or other separators. This can cause the product to access resources in a parent path.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename....' (Multiple Trailing Dot)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple trailing dot ('filedir....') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Deployment of Wrong Handler
items.summary: The wrong "handler" is assigned to process an object.

items.name: Missing Handler
items.summary: A handler is not available or implemented.

items.name: Dangerous Signal Handler not Disabled During Sensitive Operations
items.summary: The product uses a signal handler that shares state with other signal handlers, but it does not properly mask or prevent those signal handlers from being invoked while the original signal handler is still running.

items.name: Unparsed Raw Web Content Delivery
items.summary: The product stores raw content or supporting code under the web document root with an extension that is not specifically handled by the server.

items.name: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
items.summary: The product allows the upload or transfer of dangerous file types that are automatically processed within its environment.

items.name: Improper Interaction Between Multiple Correctly-Behaving Entities
items.summary: An interaction error occurs when two entities have correct behavior when running independently of each other, but when they are integrated as components in a larger system or process, they introduce incorrect behaviors that may cause resultant weaknesses.

items.name: Interpretation Conflict
items.summary: Product A handles inputs or steps differently than Product B, which causes A to perform incorrect actions based on its perception of B's state.

items.name: Incomplete Model of Endpoint Features
items.summary: A product acts as an intermediary or monitor between two or more endpoints, but it does not have a complete model of an endpoint's features, behaviors, or state, potentially causing the product to perform incorrect actions based on this incomplete model.

items.name: Behavioral Change in New Version or Environment
items.summary: A's behavior or functionality changes with a new version of A, or a new environment, which is not known (or manageable) by B.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'file.name' (Internal Dot)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of internal dot ('file.ordir') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Expected Behavior Violation
items.summary: A feature, API, or function does not perform according to its specification.

items.name: Unintended Proxy or Intermediary ('Confused Deputy')
items.summary: The product receives a request, message, or directive from an upstream component, but the product does not sufficiently preserve the original source of the request before forwarding the request to an external actor that is outside of the product's control sphere. This causes the product to appear to be the source of the request, leading it to act as a proxy or other intermediary between the upstream component and the external actor.

items.name: DEPRECATED: HTTP response splitting
items.summary: This weakness can be found at CWE-113.

items.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')
items.summary: The product acts as an intermediary HTTP agent (such as a proxy or firewall) in the data flow between two entities such as a client and server, but it does not interpret malformed HTTP requests or responses in ways that are consistent with how the messages will be processed by those entities that are at the ultimate destination.

items.name: UI Discrepancy for Security Feature
items.summary: The user interface does not correctly enable or configure a security feature, but the interface provides feedback that causes the user to believe that the feature is in a secure state.

items.name: Unimplemented or Unsupported Feature in UI
items.summary: A UI function for a security feature appears to be supported and gives feedback to the user that suggests that it is supported, but the underlying functionality is not implemented.

items.name: Obsolete Feature in UI
items.summary: A UI function is obsolete and the product does not warn the user.

items.name: The UI Performs the Wrong Action
items.summary: The UI performs the wrong action with respect to the user's request.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'file...name' (Multiple Internal Dot)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple internal dot ('file...dir') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Multiple Interpretations of UI Input
items.summary: The UI has multiple interpretations of user input but does not prompt the user when it selects the less secure interpretation.

items.name: User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information
items.summary: The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user, allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks.

items.name: Insecure Default Variable Initialization
items.summary: The product, by default, initializes an internal variable with an insecure or less secure value than is possible.

items.name: External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores
items.summary: The product initializes critical internal variables or data stores using inputs that can be modified by untrusted actors.

items.name: Non-exit on Failed Initialization
items.summary: The product does not exit or otherwise modify its operation when security-relevant errors occur during initialization, such as when a configuration file has a format error or a hardware security module (HSM) cannot be activated, which can cause the product to execute in a less secure fashion than intended by the administrator.

items.name: Missing Initialization of a Variable
items.summary: The product does not initialize critical variables, which causes the execution environment to use unexpected values.

items.name: Use of Uninitialized Variable
items.summary: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Incorrect Initialization
items.summary: This weakness has been deprecated because its name and description did not match. The description duplicated CWE-454, while the name suggested a more abstract initialization problem. Please refer to CWE-665 for the more abstract problem.

items.name: Incomplete Cleanup
items.summary: The product does not properly "clean up" and remove temporary or supporting resources after they have been used.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename ' (Trailing Space)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing space ('filedir ') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Improper Cleanup on Thrown Exception
items.summary: The product does not clean up its state or incorrectly cleans up its state when an exception is thrown, leading to unexpected state or control flow.

items.name: Duplicate Key in Associative List (Alist)
items.summary: Duplicate keys in associative lists can lead to non-unique keys being mistaken for an error.

items.name: Deletion of Data Structure Sentinel
items.summary: The accidental deletion of a data-structure sentinel can cause serious programming logic problems.

items.name: Addition of Data Structure Sentinel
items.summary: The accidental addition of a data-structure sentinel can cause serious programming logic problems.

items.name: Return of Pointer Value Outside of Expected Range
items.summary: A function can return a pointer to memory that is outside of the buffer that the pointer is expected to reference.

items.name: Use of sizeof() on a Pointer Type
items.summary: The code calls sizeof() on a pointer type, which can be an incorrect calculation if the programmer intended to determine the size of the data that is being pointed to.

items.name: Incorrect Pointer Scaling
items.summary: In C and C++, one may often accidentally refer to the wrong memory due to the semantics of when math operations are implicitly scaled.

items.name: Use of Pointer Subtraction to Determine Size
items.summary: The product subtracts one pointer from another in order to determine size, but this calculation can be incorrect if the pointers do not exist in the same memory chunk.

items.name: Path Equivalence: ' filename' (Leading Space)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of leading space (' filedir') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')
items.summary: The product uses external input with reflection to select which classes or code to use, but it does not sufficiently prevent the input from selecting improper classes or code.

items.name: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID)
items.summary: The product does not properly protect an assumed-immutable element from being modified by an attacker.

items.name: External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter
items.summary: The web application does not sufficiently verify inputs that are assumed to be immutable but are actually externally controllable, such as hidden form fields.

items.name: PHP External Variable Modification
items.summary: A PHP application does not properly protect against the modification of variables from external sources, such as query parameters or cookies. This can expose the application to numerous weaknesses that would not exist otherwise.

items.name: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
items.summary: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions.

items.name: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
items.summary: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

items.name: NULL Pointer Dereference
items.summary: The product dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid but is NULL.

items.name: Use of Obsolete Function
items.summary: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

items.name: Missing Default Case in Multiple Condition Expression
items.summary: The code does not have a default case in an expression with multiple conditions, such as a switch statement.

items.name: Signal Handler Use of a Non-reentrant Function
items.summary: The product defines a signal handler that calls a non-reentrant function.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'file name' (Internal Whitespace)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of internal space ('file(SPACE)name') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Use of Incorrect Operator
items.summary: The product accidentally uses the wrong operator, which changes the logic in security-relevant ways.

items.name: Assigning instead of Comparing
items.summary: The code uses an operator for assignment when the intention was to perform a comparison.

items.name: Comparing instead of Assigning
items.summary: The code uses an operator for comparison when the intention was to perform an assignment.

items.name: Incorrect Block Delimitation
items.summary: The code does not explicitly delimit a block that is intended to contain 2 or more statements, creating a logic error.

items.name: Omitted Break Statement in Switch
items.summary: The product omits a break statement within a switch or similar construct, causing code associated with multiple conditions to execute. This can cause problems when the programmer only intended to execute code associated with one condition.

items.name: Comparison of Classes by Name
items.summary: The product compares classes by name, which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name.

items.name: Reliance on Package-level Scope
items.summary: Java packages are not inherently closed; therefore, relying on them for code security is not a good practice.

items.name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session
items.summary: The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions, causing data to be provided to, or used by, the wrong session.

items.name: Active Debug Code
items.summary: The product is released with debugging code still enabled or active.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'filename/' (Trailing Slash)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing slash ('filedir/') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')
items.summary: A class has a cloneable() method that is not declared final, which allows an object to be created without calling the constructor. This can cause the object to be in an unexpected state.

items.name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data
items.summary: Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers.

items.name: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier
items.summary: The product has a critical public variable that is not final, which allows the variable to be modified to contain unexpected values.

items.name: Download of Code Without Integrity Check
items.summary: The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code.

items.name: Private Data Structure Returned From A Public Method
items.summary: The product has a method that is declared public, but returns a reference to a private data structure, which could then be modified in unexpected ways.

items.name: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field
items.summary: Assigning public data to a private array is equivalent to giving public access to the array.

items.name: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
items.summary: The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does.

items.name: Cloneable Class Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class is cloneable. The data can then be accessed by cloning the class.

items.name: Serializable Class Containing Sensitive Data
items.summary: The code contains a class with sensitive data, but the class does not explicitly deny serialization. The data can be accessed by serializing the class through another class.

items.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Data Transmission Without Encryption
items.summary: Information sent over a network can be compromised while in transit. An attacker may be able to read or modify the contents if the data are sent in plaintext or are weakly encrypted.

items.name: Path Equivalence: '//multiple/leading/slash'
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple leading slash ('//multiple/leading/slash') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Public Static Field Not Marked Final
items.summary: An object contains a public static field that is not marked final, which might allow it to be modified in unexpected ways.

items.name: Trust Boundary Violation
items.summary: The product mixes trusted and untrusted data in the same data structure or structured message.

items.name: Deserialization of Untrusted Data
items.summary: The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently ensuring that the resulting data will be valid.

items.name: Embedded Malicious Code
items.summary: The product contains code that appears to be malicious in nature.

items.name: Trojan Horse
items.summary: The product appears to contain benign or useful functionality, but it also contains code that is hidden from normal operation that violates the intended security policy of the user or the system administrator.

items.name: Non-Replicating Malicious Code
items.summary: Non-replicating malicious code only resides on the target system or product that is attacked; it does not attempt to spread to other systems.

items.name: Replicating Malicious Code (Virus or Worm)
items.summary: Replicating malicious code, including viruses and worms, will attempt to attack other systems once it has successfully compromised the target system or the product.

items.name: Path Equivalence: '/multiple//internal/slash'
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple internal slash ('/multiple//internal/slash/') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Trapdoor
items.summary: A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input, allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism.

items.name: Logic/Time Bomb
items.summary: The product contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the product (or its environment) when a certain time passes, or when a certain logical condition is met.

items.name: Spyware
items.summary: The product collects personally identifiable information about a human user or the user's activities, but the product accesses this information using other resources besides itself, and it does not require that user's explicit approval or direct input into the product.

items.name: Covert Channel
items.summary: A covert channel is a path that can be used to transfer information in a way not intended by the system's designers.

items.name: Covert Storage Channel
items.summary: A covert storage channel transfers information through the setting of bits by one program and the reading of those bits by another. What distinguishes this case from that of ordinary operation is that the bits are used to convey encoded information.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Covert Timing Channel
items.summary: This weakness can be found at CWE-385.

items.name: Path Equivalence: '/multiple/trailing/slash//'
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple trailing slash ('/multiple/trailing/slash//') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: .NET Misconfiguration: Use of Impersonation
items.summary: Allowing a .NET application to run at potentially escalated levels of access to the underlying operating and file systems can be dangerous and result in various forms of attacks.

items.name: Weak Password Requirements
items.summary: The product does not require that users should have strong passwords.

items.name: Insufficiently Protected Credentials
items.summary: The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

items.name: Unprotected Transport of Credentials
items.summary: Login pages do not use adequate measures to protect the user name and password while they are in transit from the client to the server.

items.name: Use of Cache Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The code uses a cache that contains sensitive information, but the cache can be read by an actor outside of the intended control sphere.

items.name: Use of Web Browser Cache Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The web application does not use an appropriate caching policy that specifies the extent to which each web page and associated form fields should be cached.

items.name: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in an Environment Variable
items.summary: The product uses an environment variable to store unencrypted sensitive information.

items.name: Exposure of Version-Control Repository to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
items.summary: The product stores a CVS, git, or other repository in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

items.name: Exposure of Core Dump File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
items.summary: The product generates a core dump file in a directory, archive, or other resource that is stored, transferred, or otherwise made accessible to unauthorized actors.

items.name: Exposure of Access Control List Files to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
items.summary: The product stores access control list files in a directory or other container that is accessible to actors outside of the intended control sphere.

items.name: Path Equivalence: '\multiple\\internal\backslash'
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of multiple internal backslash ('\multiple\trailing\\slash') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Exposure of Backup File to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
items.summary: A backup file is stored in a directory or archive that is made accessible to unauthorized actors.

items.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Test Code
items.summary: Accessible test applications can pose a variety of security risks. Since developers or administrators rarely consider that someone besides themselves would even know about the existence of these applications, it is common for them to contain sensitive information or functions.

items.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
items.summary: The product writes sensitive information to a log file.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Server Log Files
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level. See CWE-532.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Debug Log Files
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level. See CWE-532.

items.name: Exposure of Information Through Shell Error Message
items.summary: A command shell error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code. In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause these errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

items.name: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.

items.name: Java Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: In many cases, an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause unhandled exception errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

items.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory
items.summary: The product places sensitive information into files or directories that are accessible to actors who are allowed to have access to the files, but not to the sensitive information.

items.name: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information
items.summary: The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information.

items.name: Path Equivalence: 'filedir\' (Trailing Backslash)
items.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing backslash ('filedir\') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

items.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
items.summary: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users.

items.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File
items.summary: If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Cleanup Log Files
items.summary: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level. See CWE-532.

items.name: Use of Singleton Pattern Without Synchronization in a Multithreaded Context
items.summary: The product uses the singleton pattern when creating a resource within a multithreaded environment.

items.name: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism
items.summary: The product does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code, which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses.

items.name: DEPRECATED: Use of Dynamic Class Loading
